Variables.description: Declares a variable, optionally initializing it to a value.
Declares a block-scoped, local variable, optionally initializing it to a value.
Declares a block-scoped, read-only named constant.

Data Types.description: Represents both integer and floating-point numbers.
Represents a logical entity having two values: true and false.
Used to store collections of data and more complex entities.
Used to store multiple values in a single variable.
Represents the intentional absence of any object value.
Indicates that a variable has not been assigned a value.

Operators.description: Compare two values and return true or false.
Used to determine the logic between variables or values.
Assign a value to a variable based on some condition.
Operators.code: let result = (x > 10) ? "Greater than 10" : "Less than or equal to 10";

Control Flow.description: Executes a block of code if a specified condition is true.
Executes a block of code if the same condition is false.
Specifies a new condition to test if the first condition is false.
Specifies many alternative blocks of code to be executed.
Loops through a block of code a number of times.
Loops through a block of code as long as a specified condition is true.
Also loops through a block of code as long as a specified condition is true.

Functions.description: Defines a function with the specified parameters.
A function can also be defined using an expression.
Allows a short syntax for writing function expressions.
A function that runs as soon as it is defined.

Scope.description: Variables defined outside any function have global scope.
Variables declared within a function are local to that function.
`let` and `const` are scoped to the block in which they are defined.
Defines how variable names are resolved in nested functions: inner functions contain the scope of parent functions even if the parent function has returned.

Array Methods.description: Adds one or more elements to the end of an array and returns the new length of the array.
Removes the last element from an array and returns that element.
Removes the first element from an array and returns that removed element.
Adds one or more elements to the beginning of an array and returns the new length of the array.
Changes the contents of an array by removing or replacing existing elements and/or adding new elements in place.
Returns a shallow copy of a portion of an array into a new array object selected from start to end (end not included).
Array Methods.code: let newColors = colors.slice(1, 3); // Copies elements at index 1 to 2

Array Methods.description: Is used to merge two or more arrays.
Array Methods.code: let moreColors = ["Pink", "Black"]; let combinedColors = colors.concat(moreColors); // Merges two arrays

Array Iteration.description: Executes a provided function once for each array element.
Creates a new array populated with the results of calling a provided function on every element in the calling array.
Creates a new array with all elements that pass the test implemented by the provided function.
Executes a reducer function on each element of the array, resulting in a single output value.
Array Iteration.code: let totalLength = colors.reduce((acc, color) => acc + color.length, 0);

Objects.description: Includes dot notation and bracket notation for accessing properties.
Objects.code:
let person = {firstName: "John", lastName: "Doe"};
// Examples for dot and bracket notation

let person = {firstName: "John", lastName: "Doe"};
// Examples for each object method

Objects.description: A JavaScript expression that allows unpacking values from arrays, or properties from objects, into distinct variables.
Accesses the property of an object. It's a straightforward syntax for getting or setting an object's property when you know the name of the property.
Another way to access a property of an object. It's useful when the property name is dynamic or not a valid identifier.
Returns an array of a given object's own property names, in the same order as we get with a normal loop.
Returns an array of a given object's own enumerable property values, in the same order as that provided by a for...in loop.
Returns an array of a given object's own enumerable string-keyed property [key, value] pairs.

Promises.description: The initial state of a Promise. The operation represented by the Promise has not completed yet.
Promises.code: const promise = new Promise((resolve, reject) => {}); // Promise is in 'Pending' state

Promises.description: The state of a Promise representing a successful operation.
Promises.code:
const promise = Promise.resolve('Success');
promise.then(result => console.log(result)); // 'Success', Promise is 'Fulfilled'

Promises.description: The state of a Promise representing a failed operation.
Promises.code:
const promise = Promise.reject('Failure');
promise.catch(error => console.log(error)); // 'Failure', Promise is 'Rejected'

Promises.description: Method to handle the fulfillment of the Promise. It gets called when the Promise is fulfilled.
Method to handle the rejection of the Promise. It is executed when the Promise is rejected.
Method that executes a callback function once the Promise is either fulfilled or rejected.
Method that takes an iterable of promises as an input, and returns a single Promise that resolves when all of the promises in the iterable have resolved.

Asynchronous JavaScript.description: A function passed into another function as an argument to be executed later.
An object representing the eventual completion or failure of an asynchronous operation.
A syntactic sugar built on top of promises, making asynchronous code look and behave a little more like synchronous code.

Error Handling.description: Marks a block of statements to try, and specifies a response, should an exception be thrown.

JSON (JavaScript Object Notation).description: A syntax for storing and exchanging data.
JSON (JavaScript Object Notation).code:
let json = '{"name": "John", "age": 30}';
let user = JSON.parse(json); // Converts JSON text into a JavaScript object

Modules.description: Allows you to bring modules or specific features into your current file.
Allows you to make parts of your module available to be imported into other files.

DOM Manipulation.description: Changing the content or style of elements.
Adding new elements to the DOM.

Events.description: Add a function that will be called whenever a specified event occurs.
The process by which an event activated on an element (e.g., a click) is propagated through multiple layers of the DOM. Event propagation can be in two phases: capturing and bubbling.

A technique of handling events by adding a single event listener to a parent element rather than multiple listeners to individual child elements. It leverages the event bubbling phase to capture events from child elements.

AJAX (Asynchronous JavaScript and XML).description: A technique for creating fast and dynamic web pages.

Fetch API.description: Provides a JavaScript interface for accessing and manipulating parts of the HTTP pipeline, such as requests and responses.

ES6+ Features.description: Allow embedded expressions and multi-line strings.
Allows unpacking values from arrays or properties from objects.
Allows an iterable to expand in places where 0+ arguments are expected.
Provide a concise syntax for writing function expressions.
Declare variables with block scope, with `let` allowing reassignment and `const` defining a constant reference.
Allow named parameters to be initialized with default values if no value or undefined is passed.
Support for import and export of functions, objects, or primitives from one module to another.
An object representing the eventual completion or failure of an asynchronous operation.

Web APIs.description: Allows web applications to store data persistently in the browser.
Similar to Local Storage but with a shorter lifecycle.
Provides mechanisms by which browsers can securely store key/value pairs, accessible within the user's session or persistently.

Libraries and Frameworks.description: A library for building user interfaces.
A platform and framework for building single-page client applications using HTML and TypeScript.
A progressive framework for building user interfaces.

Debugging.description: Logs information to the browser's console.
A debugging tool that allows developers to pause the execution of code at a specific line, enabling the inspection of variables and the flow of execution at that moment.
Debugging.code:
// No direct code example for setting breakpoints through source code,
// but most developer tools allow you to click on the line number in the source to set a breakpoint.

Debugging.description: A set of web developer tools built into most web browsers that help in debugging web pages. They provide insights into the DOM, styles, JavaScript, network activity, performance, and more.

Others.description: A feature where an inner function has access to the outer (enclosing) functionâ€™s variables.
Functions passed as arguments to other functions to be executed at a later time.
The mechanism by which JavaScript objects inherit features from one another.
Refers to the object it belongs to.
The behavior of moving declarations to the top of their scope before code execution.
A way to opt in to a restricted variant of JavaScript.

Advanced JavaScript Concepts.description: A primitive data type unique and immutable, used mainly as the key of an Object property.
Functions that can be exited and later re-entered, with their context saved across re-entrances.
An object that wraps another object and intercepts operations, like reading/writing properties and others, optionally providing custom behavior.

Modern Development Practices.description: Scripts that your browser runs in the background, separate from a web page, opening the door to features that don't need a web page or user interaction.
A set of web platform APIs that allow you to create new custom, reusable, encapsulated HTML tags to use in web pages and web apps.

Testing and Performance.description: A type of software testing where individual units or components of a software are tested.

Security.description: A security vulnerability typically found in web applications that allows attackers to inject client-side scripts into web pages viewed by other users.
Security.code: // Example omitted for security best practices

ES6+ Features Extended.description: A safe way to access nested object properties, even if an intermediate property doesn't exist.
A logical operator that returns its right-hand side operand when its left-hand side operand is null or undefined, and otherwise returns its left-hand side operand.
